title: Corporate Spending on AI: The Shift Impacting Salesforce and Enterprise Apps
description: Exploring how companies are shifting budgets toward AI and what it means for traditional enterprise applications.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into a fascinating trend reshaping enterprise IT budgets—companies are making a significant shift in their spending toward artificial intelligence, specifically generative AI, and what that shift means for traditional enterprise applications, such as Salesforce. This episode is based on an insightful piece from *The Information*, titled 'Corporate Spending on OpenAI Threatens Salesforce, Other Enterprise Apps,' by Aaron Holmes.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, here’s the big picture: while AI is positioned as the next transformative technology for the business world, companies are making room for these new tools within existing budgets rather than expanding them. This means they’re reducing spending in other areas, particularly on established enterprise applications and non-AI cloud services. Companies that provide these legacy applications, like Salesforce, may start to feel the financial pinch.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Take, for example, a company called C1 based in Bloomington, Minnesota. C1 is a leader in software for heating and cooling systems, with over a billion dollars in annual revenue. Their CIO, Viral Tripathi, shared that C1 has carved out about 5-8% of their IT budget specifically for conversational AI, including a new customer service chatbot. Additionally, they’re developing their own AI-powered customer relationship management, or CRM, software, using models from OpenAI. This strategy, C1 believes, will allow them to save on enterprise apps and reduce overall IT expenses.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But it’s not just C1. The article mentions large cloud providers like Amazon Web Services reporting similar shifts in client budgets. Clients are 'optimizing'—which often means reducing—other software expenses to make room for AI.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Salesforce and other traditional enterprise software providers aren’t standing by idly, though. Salesforce’s own marketing executive, Patrick Stokes, argues that trying to replace established enterprise apps with AI may not be worth the cost or complexity, especially given the integration of deep workflows within Salesforce and similar applications. So while AI is gaining traction, Salesforce believes companies may ultimately find it more difficult than expected to fully switch away.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Still, the enthusiasm around generative AI’s potential cost-savings is strong. Companies are using language models for various tasks—everything from customer support automation to internal data processing. For instance, mortgage lending firm Rocket Companies built AI tools to extract data from mortgage documents and streamline customer support, replacing or 'sunsetting' older, more manual systems.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And then there’s a cost-saving story from Runway, a finance software firm whose CEO, Siqi Chen, explained that by building ad-tracking tools with OpenAI models, they save considerably on software that would otherwise have cost them up to $40,000 a year.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Of course, this trend is boosting AI developers like OpenAI. The article reports that OpenAI projected around $4 billion in revenue this year, a significant jump from last year’s $1 billion. Many large corporations, such as T-Mobile, have even signed high-profile contracts, with T-Mobile committing $100 million over three years for AI-powered customer service software.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This shift also impacts the major cloud providers supporting these AI developments. Microsoft, Google, and Amazon have invested heavily in infrastructure to support AI growth. Microsoft, for example, attributes a significant portion of its cloud revenue growth to AI, though it primarily comes from its collaboration with OpenAI. Amazon’s AWS is benefiting similarly through a partnership with Anthropic, an OpenAI competitor.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: For some companies, however, fully replacing traditional enterprise applications with AI may not be realistic. Toyota, for instance, sees generative AI as an essential part of its future budget but remains cautious about trying to replace core business processes or apps that handle critical data and workflows.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Interestingly, there are companies finding that AI tools allow them to optimize staffing as well. Autodesk, for instance, implemented AI models for customer support and saw a 63% boost in productivity. They also use AI coding tools like GitHub Copilot to automate coding tasks, achieving about 30% productivity gains, which has influenced their hiring plans.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: All in all, this AI shift is proving to be a double-edged sword for the tech industry. AI developers like OpenAI are reaping rewards, but legacy software companies, from CRM providers like Salesforce to complex ERP vendors, face the challenge of justifying their traditional software’s value against these new AI-based solutions.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what does this mean for the future of enterprise software? As companies look to cut costs and optimize, we may see more businesses adopting in-house AI tools over purchasing from traditional vendors. But legacy enterprise apps won’t disappear overnight. Many companies, especially those lacking large development teams, will still rely on them for key functions.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Ultimately, this is a new phase of enterprise technology—a dynamic landscape where the balance between cost-saving AI solutions and established, reliable enterprise applications is constantly evolving. It’s an exciting time to be watching these developments.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thank you for tuning into 'Life is Artificial.' I hope you enjoyed today’s look into how AI is shaking up enterprise software budgets. Be sure to check out *The Information* for the full article by Aaron Holmes. Until next time, stay curious, stay informed, and keep exploring the world of artificial intelligence.
